title: Applications Developer Intermediate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Geisinger (Danville, PA)
Interview Descriptions:
I was called in for an interview. I met with three separate people from the team. Had a 2 hour interview first hour with the head of the team and the second with the team coordinator.  First two went well and were fairly straightforward, I left feeling very very positive. 

Then I had an hour and a half interview with a senior member of the team who began asking me to regurgitate specific code onto a white board. He was not very pleasant and really put me on the spot, I was not aware I would be taking a written on the spot exam. I tried to explain that my body of work which he has access to would show I know my stuff but he insisted that I be able to throw code on a white board at his whim. 

That last part really threw it off for me and I left embarrassed and rather angry. In this day and age I've never been asked to write code out on a white board and as a person who has interviewed developers I would never expect that of someone.
Interview Questions: What kind of development are you doing in your current position?

title: Clinical Exercise Physiologist Interview

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Geisinger (Bloomsburg, PA) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions: I applied online, took a personality test, and then received an email to setup a phone interview. Setup a phone interview. Had the phone interview and then came in like a week later for a scheduled in-person interview. I was told it was going to be a panel interview. I show up and I'm given an IQ Test with antiquated coding questions, some of which were in C and some of which were in COBOL. This is wrong for many reasons, because mainly IQ tests have been studied over the years and aren't an accurate measure of anyone's intelligence. After failing this interview because I have an anxiety disorder that can make it extremely hard to do testing, I was ghosted by Geisinger and they no longer even reply to my applications. Probably not worth it for a company that has such discriminatory hiring practices. I'd imagine, they would be as inconsiderate in the workplace.
Interview Questions: Write a fruit constructing machine that creates fruit objects and then sorts them based on what type of fruit is produced.

title: Physician Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Geisinger (Wilkes-Barre, PA) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions:
First, you need to submit an application through the online portal
Next, you will be contacted by a recruiter if they feel you are a fit for the position
The first interview is with an HR recruiter who will provide general information regarding the position and the company and find out a little more about you.
The second interview was a half day interview with various individuals including regional management and department physicians asking more in depth questions about your qualifications, why you are interested in the job, and why you would be the best fit and best person for the position.
If an offer is made, the same HR recruiter will call you with the offer and a start date should you accept.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

The tour with several different people also factors into the decision-making even though it isn't officially a formal interview.  Overall it is structured very well with lots of opportunities to ask questions and dig into the specifics of the program.  Your willingness to ask meaningful questions and share your observations is noticed.
Interview Questions: Why residency now? A tiny little question opening up an enormous swath of my life.

title: Human Resources Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Geisinger (Danville, PA) in Jun 2009
Interview Descriptions: Met with group of current HR employees, supervisor and head of HR.  Perception is that they are overworked and understaffed.  The group of current HR employees said several times that they used to be able to return calls within 24 hours and the time keeps increasing.  I left with the feeling they cannot keep up with the demands of the growing company.  The head of HR asked questions 'off the top of his head' and when I left the office I questioned if I wanted to work in that department at this company since I did not like the demeanor of the supervisory staff.  I was told they met as a group to compare notes and make a hiring decision.
